title: 105_s1281
content: The "Indian Employment and Training Improvement Act of 1997" amends sections of the Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 regarding plan review and approval, including waivers of statutory requirements by tribal governments. SEC. 4. JOB CREATION ACTIVITIES. Section 9 of the Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 is amended to allow tribal governments to use a percentage of funds for creating employment opportunities, including private sector training placements. Tribal governments can use a percentage of funds based on the rate of unemployment in the area or 10 percent for creating employment opportunities. Federal responsibilities are outlined in Section 5. The Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 is amended to ensure an orderly transition in the administration of integrated programs, eliminating adverse effects on Indian tribes with self-determination contracts. The Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act is amended to transfer personnel and resources from the Bureau of Indian Affairs to the Office of Self-Governance within the Department of the Interior. SEC. 6 amends the Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 to assign federal personnel to Indian economic development programs. SEC. 7 adds a consolidated advisory committee to the Act. SEC. 19 allows tribal governments to establish a consolidated advisory committee to oversee integrated programs under the Act, with waivers for any statutory requirements. SEC. 8 pertains to Alaska Regional Consortia. SEC. 8 of the Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 allows for the establishment of Alaska Regional Consortia. The Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 allows for the establishment of Alaska Regional Consortia, where Alaska Native villages or corporations can carry out projects through a resolution adopted by their governing bodies. Participants can withdraw from the program at any time after its implementation.
